chapter: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question: Question 1: When should an elective caesarean section ideally be performed?
questions.explanation: An elective caesarean section should ideally be performed after 39 weeks. It is not done before 39 weeks of gestation as there is an increased risk of: • Complications related to prematurity including respiratory problems • Neonatal adaptation problems such as hypothermia and hypoglycemia
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 2: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is set to undergo an elective LSCS 2 days later. What is the 
ideal time to administer antibiotics to this patient?
questions.explanation:
According to ACOG guidelines, the ideal time to administer antibiotics is within a time period of 
60 mins prior to the planned caesarean section. Antimicrobial administration before surgical incision has been shown to lower postoperative 
infection rates without adverse neonatal effects, as compared with drug administration after 
umbilical cord clamping. A 1 g dose of cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice. For emergency delivery, antibiotic prophylaxis should be given as soon as possible.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 3: The partogram of a 26-year-old G2P1 woman is shown below. What is the prophylactic 
antibiotic of choice for this patient before definitive management is done? 272 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above partogram is suggestive of obstructed labour and the definitive management in this 
case is caesarean section. Cefazolin is an efficacious and cost-effective choice for antibiotic 
prophylaxis before caesarean section. According to the partogram, there is a secondary arrest of dilatation for >2 hours and arrest of 
descent for >1 hour. The amniotic fluid is stained with meconium and there is fall in fetal heart 
rate indicating fetal distress. Hence, the management plan is to perform a caesarean section. The recommended prophylactic drug is a single intravenous dose of a -lactam antimicrobial. This 
could either be a cephalosporin or an extended-spectrum penicillin derivative. A 1 g dose of 
cefazolin is usually given. For obese women, a 2 g dose is better to provide an adequate coverage.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 4: You are asked to administer antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis to a patient 
posted for elective LSCS. What condition does the patient likely have?
questions.explanation:
Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis before surgical procedures is recommended 
in patients with prosthetic valves, prior history of endocarditis, and unrepaired cyanotic heart 
diseases. Pregnant women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease, 
prosthetic valves, or both. However, endocarditis prophylaxis is not required if the patient is 
already receiving intrapartum prophylaxis with broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent 
endometritis. Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for atrial septal defect (ASD). The risk of endocarditis 
with ASD is negligible. Bacterial endocarditis is associated with unrepaired ventricular septal 279 
Sold by @itachibot defects where antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended. Similarly, prophylaxis for bacterial 
endocarditis is indicated at delivery for unrepaired patent ductus arteriosus.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 5: A 25-year-old obese pregnant woman is scheduled for caesarean section. While going through 
her file, you find that she is allergic to penicillin. What is/are the antibiotic(s) you would 
prescribe for her?
questions.explanation:
In an obese pregnant woman who is allergic to penicillin, a dose of 900 mg clindamycin with an 
aminoglycoside is used for antibiotic prophylaxis. In women with significant penicillin or cephalosporin allergy, a single 600 mg intravenous dose of 
clindamycin combined with a weight-based dose of aminoglycoside is recommended. For obese 
women, a 900 mg dose is preferred.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 6: A woman with preeclampsia presents with haemorrhage at 38 weeks of gestation. You decide 
to perform a caesarean section and terminate the pregnancy. What is the anaesthesia of 
choice?
questions.explanation:
General anaesthesia is the anaesthesia of choice here since the patient presents with 
haemorrhage. General anaesthesia may be indicated for emergency cesarean delivery in patients with a 
reassuring airway examination. It is also recommended for patients with severe coagulopathy 
where neuraxial anesthesia is contraindicated. Spinal anesthesia is not preferred when the operation is expected to result in blood loss or in a 
previously haemorrhaging patient. It is because in such cases the development of severe 
hypovolemia is likely which is a contraindication for this type of anaesthesia.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 7: An elective cesarean section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected 
cephalopelvic disproportion. In which of the following abdominal incisions are the recti 
muscles transected?
questions.explanation:
The recti muscles are transected in the Maylard incision for caesarean delivery which is marked as 
'2' in the given image. It is a variation of the Pfannenstiel incision in which the rectus abdominis muscles are sectioned 
transversely to permit wider access to the pelvis. It is also known as the Mackenrodt incision. The various incisions mentioned in the image are: Incision '1' - Midline vertical incision is made in the middle extending from just below the 
umbilicus to just above the symphysis pubis. This is used less commonly compared to the 
transverse abdominal incision. Incision '3' - Joel Cohen is a straight incision higher than the Pfannenstiel incision. The fascia was 
incised transversely in the midline then extended laterally with blunt finger dissection; finger 
dissection was used to separate the rectus muscles vertically and laterally. Incision '4' - Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery. It 
follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the 
skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. 280 
Sold by @itachibot This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, 
the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain 
entry to the peritoneum.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 8: All of the following are benefits of using a transverse abdominal incision for caesarean 
delivery in a patient except 
.
questions.explanation: Transverse abdominal incisions offer a narrow operating space.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 9: An elective C-section is being performed in a primigravida due to suspected contracted pelvis. 
After opening the abdomen through a modified Pfannenstiel incision, the obstetrician makes 
a low transverse uterine incision. How should this incision be extended?

options.a: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each index finger
options.b: By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each index finger
options.c: By applying lateral and slightly upward pressure with each thumb
options.d: By applying lateral and slightly downward pressure with each thumb

questions.explanation:
In a C-section, the incision on the uterus can be extended by using lateral and slightly upward 
pressure applied with each index finger. If the lower uterine segment is thick, then cutting laterally and then slightly upward with bandage 
scissors will extend the incision. Note: When scissors are used, the index and middle fingers of the non-dominant hand should be 
insinuated between the myometrium and the fetal parts to prevent fetal laceration.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 10: The highest risk of uterine rupture is seen with 
.
questions.explanation:
A T-shaped incision has the highest risk of uterine rupture among the given options. Among all 
the incisions, a previous classical cesarean incision has the highest risk of rupture but it is not an 
option here. Overall, the maximum risk of uterine rupture is in patients who have had a previous upper 
segment uterine rupture. Women with single prior low-transverse hysterotomy have the lowest 
risk of symptomatic scar separation. 281 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 11: An obstetrician performing a C-section exteriorises the uterus before performing uterine 
repair. All of the following are true about this procedure except 
.

options.a: Incision and bleeding points are easily visualized and repaired
options.b: Relaxed/atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied
options.c: Vomiting and discomfort is caused by traction due to exteriorization
options.d: Adnexal exposure is low so tubal sterilization is difficult

questions.explanation:
Adnexal exposure is high and hence tubal sterilization is easy. After delivery of the placenta, the uterus is lifted through the incision onto the draped abdominal 
wall. The fundus is covered with a moistened laparotomy sponge and this is known as 
exteriorisation of uterus. Benefits of exteriorization: • Relaxed, atonic uterus can be recognized quickly and massage applied. • The incision and bleeding points are more easily visualized and repaired. • Adnexal exposure is superior, and thus, tubal sterilization is easier. Drawbacks of exteriorization: • Intraoperative nausea and vomiting • Need for additional uterotonics • Longer time duration to the first recognized bowel movement The below image shows the exteriorisation of the uterus.
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy?
questions.explanation:
Cervical cancer is not an indication for peripartum hysterectomy. Indications for peripartum hysterectomy include: • Uterine atony - when every other method fails to control PPH • Uterine extension 282 
Sold by @itachibot • Uterine rupture • Postpartum uterine infection • Cervical laceration • Leiomyoma - large leiomyomas in a woman with completed family • Ovarian neoplasia
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section?
questions.explanation:
Skin laceration is the most common fetal injury associated with caesarean section. Other injuries 
seen include: • Cephalohematoma • Brachial plexus injury • Clavicular fracture • Skull fracture • Facial nerve palsy
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 14: An elective caesarean section is planned for a pregnant woman with a cardiac ailment. Which 
of the following complications is she not at an increased risk for?
questions.explanation:
Elective caesarean section decreases the risk of chorioamnionitis. Maternal complications increase with caesarean section when compared with vaginal deliveries. 
Some of these complications include: • Post-operative infection • Haemorrhage • Thromboembolism • Anaesthesia-related complications • Mendelson syndrome/ aspiration pneumonitis
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? 276 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a pneumatic compression device. It is used in women who are not on any 
thromboprophylaxis and planned for cesarean section (statement A) and it is discontinued once 
the patient starts ambulating post-surgery (statement C). The device is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism. According to recent guidelines, patients with no additional risk factors and not placed on any 
pharmacological thromboprophylaxis are placed on pneumatic compression devices before 283 
Sold by @itachibot cesarean delivery. Patients undergoing cesarean delivery with additional risk factors are put on 
both pneumatic compression devices and pharmacological therapy (UFH or LMWH). 
UFH-unfractionated heparin, LMWH-lower molecular weight heparin. Indications of pharmacological thromboprophylaxis: • Inherited coagulation disorder • Overweight or obese patient • Heart failure • Family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 16: The risk factors for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section include all 
except 
.
questions.explanation:
Age >35 years is a risk factor for venous thromboembolism after caesarean section. The other 
risk factors include: • Emergency cesarean • Obesity • Parity >3 • Caesarean hysterectomy • Concurrent infection • Preeclampsia • Prior deep-vein thrombosis or thrombophilia
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 17: A 28-year-old multigravida with a history of C-section is being considered for vaginal delivery. 
The presence of which of the following features would categorise this procedure as low risk?
questions.explanation:
Transverse incision in prior caesarean section is a low risk factor in vaginal birth after cesarean 
(VBAC). Risk factors for VBAC: High risk - • Classical or T-incision in prior cesarean • Prior rupture • Obstetrical contraindication such as placenta previa • Inadequate facilities Low risk - • Transverse incision in prior cesarean • Prior vaginal delivery • Sufficient personnel and equipment 284 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa

questions.question:
Question 18: A trial of scar is performed on a G2P1L1 woman. The risk of which of the following 
complications is increased in this baby when compared to their elder sibling?

options.a: The number of muscle fibres decrease
options.c: The uterus weighs 1000g by 1 week postpartum

questions.explanation:
Hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) in neonates has a higher incidence with trial of scar 
or VBAC as compared to elective cesarean. Uterine rupture is a dangerous complication of VBAC. This leads to hemorrhage which can cause 
the baby to be hypoxic eventually leading to permanent brain damage from hypoxic-ischemic 
encephalopathy. This results in developmental delay and cerebral palsy. Birth trauma, transient tachypnea of newborn (TTN) and neonatal sepsis are more commonly 
seen with elective caesarean in comparison to VBAC. 285 
Sold by @itachibot Puerperium
questions.chapter_heading: Caesarean Section and Vaginal Birth After Caesa
